data.text: Contents
Introduction

Toys may be implicated in the transmission of potentially harmful pathogens and the development of infections in a vulnerable client group. Steps must be taken to ensure that toys are maintained in a safe and usable state by regular inspection, scheduled cleaning and appropriate storage.
To reduce the risk of cross infection, all toys and equipment must be made of a material that, where possible, allows effective cleaning and decontamination.
Scope

To ensure that all staff who are working in areas where toys are kept for public use, or who use toys in their day to day work, become aware of the correct procedures for their selection, handling and cleaning of toys, to minimise infection risk.
Definitions

table_items.text: a process that physically removes contamination, but does not necessarily destroy micro-organisms
the transfer of organisms from one person to another; this may or may not lead to illness or disease
Director of Infection Prevention and Control

The process used to reduce the number micro-organisms but which may not destroy bacteria spores or some viruses. Disinfection is considered to reduce the number of micro- organisms to a level that is safe for the purpose for which the piece of equipment is intended to be used.

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust

Infection Prevention and Control Site Committee (IPCC) is responsible for the review of this policy at least every three years, but more frequently if there are changes to Infection Prevention and Control Legislation or guidance.
Chief Executive
The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for the strategic and operational management of the Trust
The Director of Infection Prevention and Control (DIPC)
The DIPC oversees development and implementation of infection prevention and control policies in accordance with the Infection Prevention and Control Strategy.
Infection Prevention and Control Team (IPCT)
Responsible for:
Ensuring that the guidelines comply with all legal, statutory and good practice guidance requirements
Providing clinical leadership with this guideline implementation
Supporting the operational implementation of this guideline by providing advice and training
Improve and sharing best practice
Review the guideline in light of the outcomes from the periodic audits and to monitor its effectiveness during routine activities
Staff
All staff employed by the Trust are responsible for adhering to this policy regardless of their role, band, discipline or service area.
Handle toys in a responsible manner
Ensure toys are decontaminated between usages by patients
Perform a risk assessment when handling toys, to reduce the risk of preventable infections
Hand Hygiene
It is important to maintain a good hand hygiene standard following the handling of contaminated toys, in accordance with the Hand Hygiene and Standard Precautions Policies.
Risk Assessment

Risk assesses the suitability and cleanability of toys prior to purchase will be undertaken by the Play Specialist Team. For instance, fabric toys should be avoided as they are not easy to clean between patients
Management
The overall responsibility for designating the cleaning of toys will be assigned by the Ward Manager /Nurse in Charge
Staff must take the responsibility for cleaning toys, and they must be aware of the cleaning requirements
A cleaning schedule must be devised and kept in an accessible place (appendix1)
A record must be kept of all cleaning activity
Toy Selection
Careful consideration must be given to how toys will be kept clean before they are purchased, and adjustments must be made to facilitate effective cleaning.

Procedures must be established to guide the on-going cleaning procedures. This must identify when items should be cleaned, and with the appropriate cleaning products dependent upon the manufacturers' guidance.
Cleaning/Decontamination Procedures
To reduce the risk of cross infection, all toys and equipment must be made of a material which, where possible, allows effective cleaning and decontamination.

All equipment and toys should be cleaned on a weekly basis. However, where possible, toys should be cleaned between each session. (It is recognised that some sessions include more than one child, and cleaning is only necessary at the end of these sessions).

Should any toy or piece of equipment become contaminated with blood or body fluids, these will require cleaning and then disinfecting using a Chlorine releasing agent (10,000 parts per million) e.g. Milton solution. Then they require rinsing and thorough drying.

Where there is an occasion when soft toys are considered an essential part of therapy, the toys must be subject to machine washing after each episode of care and thorough air/tumble drying (according to the manufacturer's instructions).
All cleaning activity must have a record entered onto a cleaning schedule (Appendix 1).
A cleaning rota must be put in place and followed for all playroom areas (Appendix 2).
Toys and activities for COVID -19 Positive patients;
9.7.1 Careful consideration must take place prior to patient's receiving toys and activities. All resources given must be made of a material that is able to undergo effective decontamination.

9.7.2 When toys are no longer in use with COVID-19 positive patients, the nursing/bed cleaning team will place toys into a red sack and store them in the toy cleaning area. The Play Team will identify that these toys are from a COVID-10 patient and will ensure that the items are decontaminated using a chlorine releasing agent (10,000 parts per million) The Play Team will wear the appropriate PPE when undertaking this task. Any toys that cannot be cleaned will be condemned and placed in a clinical waste bag.
Soft Toys
Soft toys must not be kept for general use in healthcare settings because they are porous, support microbial growth and can be difficult to decontaminate.

There may be occasions when soft toys form an essential part of a therapy session. Repeated decontamination of soft toys can compromise the integrity of the fabric and create a choking hazard, therefore ensure thorough checking takes place before and after use /cleaning. Toys in such condition should be discarded if needed.

Children must not be discouraged from bringing their own soft toys to hospital. Should they bring their own toy into hospital, then that toy must be used only by that child and then taken home. When a child is an inpatient the toy should be labelled as belonging to that child, and should leave the hospital when that child is discharged.
New soft toys given to the patient in hospital are acceptable with the same single rule as their own toy. The toy may be taken home with the child, or destroyed on discharge.
Hard Surface Toys
All toys must have a smooth, non-porous surface that is easy to clean.
Toys with moving parts or openings can harbour dirt and germs in the crevices. They must be washed and scrubbed using soap and warm water/detergent wipes before thorough rinsing and drying.

Small items such as ‘Lego' bricks should be soaked for a period of 5 minutes in a Chlorine based solution (10,000 parts per million) e.g. Milton, and then air dried following use by a child with a transmissible organism.
Mechanical/Electrical Toys
Mechanical/electrical toys must have their surfaces wiped weekly using Clinell universal wipes.
Books

Books must be inspected weekly and their surfaces wiped using Clinell wipes. As they have a potential for soaking up water, books with signs of dampness or mildew must be discarded. They may require frequent replacement.
Ball Pools
These should be inspected daily for cleanliness, debris and foreign items. Routine cleaning must be carried out on a monthly basis using warm water and neutral detergent and then dried thoroughly.
Dressing up Clothing
Dressing up can form an important part of a child's therapy or rehabilitation. However, only use when necessary for therapy, and the following should be taken into consideration.
For use in outpatient setting/cases of one to one therapeutic or preparatory play:

All clothes must be washable, and washed at a temperature of 60°C for 10 minutes. If kept together in a bin or on a rail, all the clothes must be laundered weekly. The storage bins must also be washed at least weekly. Clothes which are visibly soiled must then be removed and washed at the correct temperature.
Second Hand Toys
Following a risk assessment, those second hand toys which have been accepted for use, must be cleaned as described earlier, prior to distribution to ward and department areas.
Individual Play Therapy
Prior to and following Play Sessions, children's hands must be cleaned. All skin lesions must be covered.
Play Dough
This must be single patient use only, and must not be shared with other children.
Play Sand
Sand pits are not to be used for general play purposes. However, for individual play therapy, sand may be used for that child and discarded after use.
Additional Cleaning Measures

If toys become contaminated with any blood/body fluids they need to be removed immediately from the area and cleaned using a chlorine releasing agent (10,000 parts  per  million)  e.g.  Milton.  If  uncertain,  seek  guidance  from  the  Infection Prevention and Control Team.
Where toys have been contaminated with specific micro-organisms, for example during an outbreak, additional decontamination procedures may be required or toys condemned.
Wash items with Chlorine releasing agent (10,000 parts per million) e.g. Milton, and air dry thoroughly.
Toy storage
There must be a designated storage area for toys.

For areas with no designated play area, such as Outpatients; there must be a designated washable storage box for toys. It must be washed and dried weekly and a record entered onto a cleaning schedule. (Appendix 1)
It is the responsibility of the ward/department to ensure that dirty toys are cleaned and removed from circulation e.g. dirty toy box (if appropriate for the area).
Training Requirements

All Trust staff to undertake Mandatory Infection Prevention and Control updates including and Donning and Doffing updates. The IPCT has primary responsibility for providing training on the policy where needed. Managers have the responsibly to support the IPCT by ensuring that staff are able to attend training sessions in response to identified needs

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the IPCC, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve policy. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Director of Harm Free Care of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
